Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Do trait correlations and demographic stochasticity alter the dynamics of evolutionarily-accelerated invasions?
Award.AbstractNarration:
The speed at which species spread across a landscape is often under-predicted because researchers do not acknowledge that dispersal and reproductive rates can respond due to natural selection. When the expansion of a harmful invasive species or a rare re-introduced species is under-predicted, societal implications can be significant. This project will correct chronic under-prediction of species' spread by measuring genetic correlations between dispersal and fecundity. Accounting for the effects of natural selection on range expansion will significantly improve management of invasive species by providing accurate estimates of their spread. The project will improve the research and training of a promising young investigator. Two undergraduate students will be trained in experimental, computational, and mathematical ecology. The researchers will develop lessons for Texas middle-school students from minority and economically-disadvantaged backgrounds to teach the causes and consequences of biological invasions, highlighting the importance of rapid evolution.

During range expansion, individuals become spatially sorted by dispersal ability. Populations at the leading edge are dominated by highly dispersive individuals that mate assortatively. Spatial sorting will increase dispersal in leading edge populations over generations when dispersal is heritable, resulting in evolutionarily-accelerated invasions. Edge populations also occur at low conspecific densities, gaining a reproductive advantage. The theory of spatial selection is based almost entirely on models. This project examines the importance of spatial selection in ecologically realistic contexts, using laboratory-based experiments and computer simulation models to understand when spatial selection is likely to play an important role in range expansion, and when, or if, it is likely to have negligible effects. It will examine how genetic correlations between dispersal and fecundity modify expectations for spatial selection, using simulation models parameterized with data from a common beetle. The researchers hypothesize that negative genetic correlations between dispersal and fecundity will mitigate the effects of spatial selection, while a positive genetic correlation will amplify the effects. The second study will examine how stochasticity interacts with spatial selection to affect invasion speed. Demographic stochasticity may slow invasions by reducing the number of individuals at the leading edge of the invasion or by weakening the signal of spatial sorting and reducing reproductive potential at the invasion edge. This signal should be further reduced as dispersal heritability decreases. The researchers will integrate these two studies to elucidate conditions under which spatial selection is more or less important as a driver of invasion dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
If you’ve recently visited a State or National Park, gone fishing, or worked in a community garden, there’s a good chance that you’ve come across information about the presence of ‘invasive species’. Invasive species are species that are not historically native to an area but can be found there, often in large numbers, after being introduced either naturally or by humans. Some invasive species are very successful in their new environments, and their population sizes can grow quickly and rapidly spread across the landscape in ways that are harmful to the area’s native species. Invasive species don’t only harm the environment; they can also harm the economy. The US Fish and Wildlife service, referencing a study published in 2005, reports that invasive species cost the United States more than $120 billion in damages every year. It is therefore important to understand how populations of invasive species spread, so that we can safeguard both natural and financial resources.

Invasive species are not the only ones whose populations spread. In fact, all populations of species can increase or decrease the size of their range if conditions allow it. If researchers study processes that are common to all spreading populations, we can not only improve our understanding of how invasive species spread, but also our understanding of how native and endangered species spread. This is especially important in our current era of human-driven global climate change. All over the world, species are expected to shift their ranges in response to changing temperatures and precipitation patterns. Having a clear understanding of how populations spread can enable scientists, natural resource managers, local communities, and elected officials to make informed decisions about how to handle the global ecosystem changes that are currently unfolding.

An essential component for understanding how populations spread is being able to predict how quickly a population will spread from one location to another, or its ‘invasion speed’. Although ecologists have been studying invasion speed for a long time, it is a complex problem that we are still working to understand. If you think about some of the factors that contribute to population spread – individuals finding mates and reproducing; interactions among predators, prey, and parasites; the ‘patchiness’ of environments across a landscape; climate changing over time; and the ability of individuals to sometimes travel very long distances – it’s easy to imagine the difficulties researchers face in trying to make predictions about how a population will spread over timescales of decades or hundreds of years.

Another important consideration is that invasion speeds are not constant, but rather they can change over time due to evolution. This happens because individuals in the population are not all equal in their ability to move from one place to another. Individuals that have exceptional ability to move from place to place – individuals that are highly ‘dispersive’ – are more likely to be found at the farthest edges of the population’s range. If this ability to disperse is passed down from parents to offspring, individuals at the edge of the population can become more dispersive with each generation. And as individuals become more dispersive, populations can spread quicker. Understanding how this evolutionary process can alter invasion speeds is the primary goal of our research.

We use a variety of methods to explore how evolution changes invasion speed. One important way is by conducting laboratory experiments with the ‘bean beetle’ Callosobruchus maculatus. The bean beetle is convenient for laboratory studies because it has a short lifecycle (approximately one month), it’s simple to maintain in the lab (the only resource it needs to survive is an ample supply of black-eyed peas), and it’s been used extensively in research studies of invasion speed. We built experimental landscapes using Petri dishes filled with black-eyed peas to measure bean beetle invasion speeds across ten generations of population spread, with and without evolution. We found some of the first experimental evidence that evolution can indeed make invasion speed faster. We ran further experiments, some with the bean beetle and some using computer simulations, to explore how population growth and reproduction can interact with dispersal ability to modify the impacts of evolution on invasion speed.

In general, our research finds that evolution has a clear and consistent impact on invasion speed: evolution can make invasions spread faster under a wide range of conditions. We also found that evolution consistently makes invasions more variable – an unexpected but important result. These results have significant consequences for decision makers who are planning for the management of spreading populations. Our research suggests that planners who do not account for evolution are likely to under-predict invasion speed, and are likely to under-estimate the full range of potential invasion outcomes.
